title: World Regions
text:
This page depicts trends withing world regions. The first graph shows the amount of money different world regions spend on education. The second graph shows the urban population within world regions from 2010 to 2021. The third graph does the same but with rural populations. The last graph shows us the urbal and rural growth rates of each world region.
#The Graphs East Asia & Pacific, North America, and Europe & Central Asia spend the most on education.





The East Asia & Pacific region has the largest urban population while Central Europe & the Baltics, and Southern and Eastern African countries have the lowest urban populations. Urban poulations for all regions are growing.





The East Asia & Pacific and South Asian regions have the largest rural populations.

title: Effect of Education on Urban and Rural Populations
text:
library(tidyverse)
library(rstanarm)
library(primer.data)


dataset <- read_csv("Data.csv") |>
  as_tibble() |>
  filter(Time == 2020)


x <- dataset |>
  mutate(Rural_PopPerc = `Rural population (% of total population) [SP.RUR.TOTL.ZS]`, Urban_PopPerc = `Urban population (% of total population) [SP.URB.TOTL.IN.ZS]`, Rural_PopGrowth = `Rural population growth (annual %) [SP.RUR.TOTL.ZG]`, Urban_PopGrowth = `Urban population growth (annual %) [SP.URB.GROW]`, Educ_Exp = `Government expenditure on education, total (% of government expenditure) [SE.XPD.TOTL.GB.ZS]`, Country_Name = `Country Name`)|>
  select(Time, Country_Name,
         Rural_PopPerc, Rural_PopGrowth, 
         Urban_PopPerc, Urban_PopGrowth,
         Educ_Exp)


data <- x |> mutate(Educ_Exp = as.numeric(Educ_Exp),
            Rural_PopPerc = as.numeric(Rural_PopPerc),
            Rural_PopGrowth = as.numeric(Rural_PopGrowth),
            Urban_PopPerc = as.numeric(Urban_PopPerc),
            Urban_PopGrowth = as.numeric(Urban_PopGrowth)) |>
            drop_na()
data

# A tibble: 180 × 7
   Time  Country_Name        Rural_PopPerc Rural_PopGrowth Urban_PopPerc
   <chr> <chr>                       <dbl>           <dbl>         <dbl>
 1 2020  Afghanistan                 74.0            2.77           26.0
 2 2020  Albania                     37.9           -2.88           62.1
 3 2020  Algeria                     26.3           -0.317          73.7
 4 2020  Andorra                     12.1            2.33           87.9
 5 2020  Angola                      33.2            1.33           66.8
 6 2020  Antigua and Barbuda         75.6            0.688          24.4
 7 2020  Argentina                    7.89          -0.540          92.1
 8 2020  Armenia                     36.7           -0.789          63.3
 9 2020  Australia                   13.8            0.389          86.2
10 2020  Austria                     41.3           -0.148          58.7
# ℹ 170 more rows
# ℹ 2 more variables: Urban_PopGrowth <dbl>, Educ_Exp <dbl>



fit_obj1 <- stan_glm(data = data,
            formula = Educ_Exp ~ Urban_PopGrowth,
            family = gaussian,
            refresh = 0,
            seed = 42)
  
fit_obj1

fit_obj2 `

title: What are the effects of education expenditure on Urban and Rural Populations?
text: How does the effects of national government expenditure on education differ from the urban population to the rural population? The data to answer the question was sourced from the World Bank Universal Indicator dataset, and then the relevant data frames were combined to analyze the relationship between government expenditure on urban populations vs. rural populations. Increased expenditure on education typically increases the urban population, decreases the rural population, but still benefits both in terms of quality of life and access to resources.

title: Expenditure On Education
text: This page shows the correlation between government expenditure on education between various factors.
